title: Customizable Lithophane Stand with Backlight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A lithophane stand for lithophanes generated by the 3DP.rocks lithophane generator. Use the outer curve template.

The customizer will generate three STL's one with the bottom, one with the top and one with both parts.

In the customizer you will need to adjust s and h according to your actual lithophane. Also you will need to adjust bottom and top thickness, this is the max thickness of your lithophane on the top and on the bottom.

I used a 12V white LED strip (2 segments of it) and a 12V, 2A power supply. You should be able to use almost any kind of LED strip with any voltage you prefer. This just happend to be what I had lying around.

author: stylesuxx

description.text:
This is a Beefy Glock Sight Press.  It's designed to be much stronger than other printable Glock Sight Presses that I've seen.  Specifically, it is strong enough to install the Truglo sights without filing down the dovetails.
This design will accommodate a slide up to 27mm wide and 22mm tall. This is just for the slide, not any measurement off the Glock website. The slide plus sight can be up to 28.4mm tall.
If the sight has straight sides then it can be up to 18.25mm wide. But if the sight has 45 degree angled sides then it can be 22.5mm wide. Different shapes will fit differently.

There are three pieces to this that should be printed separately:  
Body:  Print using 0.2mm layers, 1 extra shell, and 100% infill.  Yes, I said 100% infill.  This is going to use a lot of plastic, but it's going to be a small fraction of what you would spend on a commercial sight press.  This is important for strength.  Epoxy/glue in a 3/8ths inch diameter hex nut.  
Slide:  You'll notice that the STL has this part at a 45 degree angle on the build plate.  This is intentional, and reduces issues on an overhang.  Print using 0.1mm layers, 1 extra shell, and 100% infill.  Once printed, break off the support and file that area smooth-ish.  Cut off two pieces of 1/8th inch thick x 1/2 inch wide steel bar stock and epoxy them to the ends of the slide.  File/sand/coat smooth the parts of the slide that will be pressing against the sight itself.  
Handle:  Print using 0.2mm layers, 3 extra shells, and 25% infill.  Once printed, epoxy in a 3/8ths inch by 3 inch long carriage bolt.  
Don't use supports for any of these pieces.  I suggest not using rafts, too, but that's up to you.  
Follow the instructions on the epoxy, and wait the required time for the epoxy to fully harden (about 24 hours for most).  This glock sight press can exert a huge amount of pressure, and you don't want to prematurely break things.  
Enjoy and shoot straight!

author: Les_Apps_de_Flo

description.text: Arch Vase 3

title: MFD Nimbus Session mount, 2-axis rotational with gear

description.text:
I created this to get two things:

  • a mount for my Session to be able to rotate it in yaw+pitch while giving it a gear for yaw to get more rotational freedom
  • a bottom plate to mount it all on (instead of the provided wooden plate) to be able to move at least one of the servos inside the nose

Two versions of the Gopro mount are available:

  • the normal version
  • the "cold" version plus a lid for it. My Session tends to die on me after a few minutes in cold weather around 0°C/32°F. If you put it in this case after warming it up in your pocket for a bit it works like a charm.

You need two servos (I used the ones from the Nimbuses tail from a crashed predecessor) and a short M3 screw plus nut for the pitch axis and a longer one (also M3) for the gear, also with nut. Feel free to ask any questions, the thing works fine for me ;)

Made this helmet based on this keychain helmet right here: https://www.cgtrader.com/free-3d-print-models/games-toys/toys/helmet-3-pubg-keyring

Changed the faceplate so you can insert a visor, also changed the bolts, attachements and made everything a single part and removed radii and chamfers so it can be easily printed. Helmet fits my head pretty snug with 10 mm foam. You need support for the visor , the helmet and the the outside boltpart.

For further informations check my video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cxzVKPaj2lE&t=60s

In the video you can see that the square side part is missing. I adjusted it's size in this version so it should fit better and match the size of the overall helmet.

You will need to print to print everything two times except the faceplate and the helmet.

This is actually the V2 of my first case, this time a bit less complex, and more slim than the first version ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2564341 )

It takes a 40mm fan of your favorite voltage, your Vtx and all cables. If you put lid and case together with some glue it should be good enough to fly in rain without damaging your vtx by water.

What to print:

  • Case with or without TBS logo
  • lid

If you own a MFD Nimbus, print all the parts and glue them to the case. You can screw it to the tail and it will be supported by the tailboom (see images)

description.text: Arch Vase 5

print_settings.Notes:: Added the Craftware project file so anyone can see how I sliced it.

description.text:
Wife wanted a cute name plate holder for her mom. mom's favorite dog is her chaweenie(sp?). Dachshund is closest I could find to that.

Chopped in half, added a slot for the name plate. Realized I had to scale to 200% so now the name plate didn't fit without help. Made some wedges to cram in behind the name plate to hold everything together. You could probably just use paper or hot glue.

Most important: the OP's model is incredibly detailed. if you want it to look good, print at .1 or .2 nozzle diam, and .1 layer height.

Wedges will also need to be scaled depending on your name plate thickness.

definitely needs supports!

These are two things that can help you to keep your Nimbus upright when on the ground. The aft one is universal while the front one depends on my Nimbus belly protector which you can find here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2593587

Rather than barely hang hangars on the wide metal rail that serves as a runner for the glass doors on our shower, I made this double-hook.
The photo shows four generations of the design.

It prints pretty easily provided that good adhesion is obtained. I use ABS glue and that works well.
Use two shells and 25% infill for strength. The final design is made to hug the contours of the rail so that it doesn't tip when one hook is used. Tweak for your rail dimensions and quirks.

Support Generated Files also provided.
Added file for 5C
Updated added hole for sim card removal on version 5
Iphone 5 - 5s case, use rubber soft type or standard filament.
If you use standard filament you will need to break the case to remove the phone. Snaps in solid! :D
Iphone 4-4s I designed this one a bit looser. It clicks onto the metal rim around the phone. It still clicks in tight but it is possible to remove.
These cases are designed to protrude out from the screen as to actually protect the screen. Many cases do not and the ones that do are bulky.
I have printed these cases for friends and have had no issues. Over the course of my printings I have improved and updated the designs slightly.

Supports should be generated to properly print the overhanging ports. Meshmixer worked well. Make sure the Open side of the case is facing up when printing.
When using rubber soft filament retraction was set to a minimum/off.

description.text:
This is a blower cooler for my aluminium carriage on my bibo 2.
Prints without supports.
Print 2 for front and back.
Snowflake ornament for a tree or anything where you can hang it on.

A centrifugal blower fan that is compatible with all EZ Twist Dremels. The lower part screws on where the EZ Twist cap would have been, the rotor is press fit onto the chuck and then the upper housing is press fit onto the lower part. The aim for this design was to not expose any moving parts while still allowing fairly easy tool exchanges. It may be a tad too large, however if you have any suggestions (including rotor redesign) i'm all ears.

There are four files, the 'Lower.stl' file should be printed flat side down with no support, same with the 'Rotor.stl' and this one preferably with 100% infill. The other two files are variants of the upper housing, one requires no support if printed flat side down, however the other has a longer nozzle, which requires support.

comments.author: EmilianoOtta

comments.text: I think this is a clever project. I don't have this type of dremel, but I've got a Milwaukee rotary tool kit that is compatible with the standard dremel collet chuck. I've attached a STL of a less-than-perfect rotor that can be threaded onto the dremel. I reduced the number of blades just to make the test prints go faster. You will have a hard time threading this on the first time, that needs more work. This does generate an impressive amount of airflow. My goal is to use this to drive the vacuum on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119410 which would make a really nice portable dust collector.

title: HTC Vive Base Station Slide-In Mounting Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted some way to mount the base stations without drilling any holes. My first idea was to use some of those adhesive mounting tapes. So I designed the brackets, which would accept the original mounting brackets. I would be able to (un)mount the base stations without having to undo any screw or having to rerun the room setup (as long as the position of the original mounting brackets on the base stations remained unchanged).

Uncertain of the whether or not the adhesive would support the weight of the base stations, I also made a bracket that would slide over the corner of my book case. This bracket is rather bulky. I wanted to be able to mount the base station both horizontally and vertically (door could get in the way). The dimensions also prevent it from tipping over. For some extra piece of mind I added a hole that matches a m3 hole in by book case, but the bracket seems to be stable/secure enough without it.

Some ca-glue was used to secure the 'slide in' bracket to the corner bracket.

Just a basic printable version of Onitama.

More about this game :
https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/160477/onitama

Not near the original minis (https://boardgamegeek.com/image/2982993/onitama) but good enough to test the game and see if you enjoy it (I did) !

Harry Potter retheme of this game : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2638576

Edit : Just seen this that baleyus made more original pawn :
Master : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2690975
Student : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2688291

The pawn are remix from bqzero hollow pawn.
I made the master a bit taller for distinction but this is doing the work just great.

The board was though to be printed with change of color after 0.5mm (black then with) to better show the engraving.

The engraving is the ideogram Aï (composed of roof/unity/speech if I believe this site : http://daikyokan-dojo.fr/aikido/signification/) which felt right for the master "dojo" :p

I put the OpenSCAD of the board if you want to edit it (thickness, etc.)

print_settings.Notes:: You could probably change the infill amount.  Also you don't need supports but I find a small "Brim" helps hold the Pic Stick when it is printing so it doesn't get knocked over.

description.text:
This is the Pic Stick!

I've seen similar ones at the store made out of wire. We needed one NOW and didn't want to travel 30 minutes to closest store. So Pic Stick was born! I use a standard shish kebab stick and the size seems to be 4.5 mm in diameter. Smaller sticks can be used with a little tape wrapped around them to make it fit snug.

How to use the Pic Stick?

Get the right size shish kebab stick that you wish to use. you can cut / break them to any length. Use the flat end of the stick to slide the Pic Stick onto it and the pointy end will go into a foam ball or block inside of a planter. (you can even just use the stick to add a note or picture into a flower arrangement) Next you will place the picture, note, craft item in between the clamp like end. If it is two tight you can slide your finger nail into it to open it up. Depending on your printer, if you have any stringing, you may need a razor blade to clear the stringing before attempting to put the picture into the holder.

author: Mosin_Nagant

title: SMD organizer rack for micro test tubes (stackable)

description.text:
I store my electrical SMD components and other small parts in 2ml micro test tubes (eppendorf tubes) as they are cheap (got 1000 + shipping for less than 20 EUR), small and also easy to handle.
I created this rack set to have them neatly stored.
The base plate can hold 40 of the 2ml test tubes. The slots are designed to align the lids all in the same direction which makes it easier to read the labels on the lids.
Also the test tubes can kind of "snap" into the slots, which prevents (or at least minimizes) "spillage" of the tubes if a rack is tilted.
The mounted racks are stackable, the side parts have slots that prevent slipping off of each other.
I included 2 sets of side parts (110mm + 170mm) that matches either the short or the long side of the base plate. Your choice!

For 1 rack set you need 1 base plate and 2 side parts of the chosen length.
For the base plate i suggest >=50% infill to make it quite solid, especially if the used filament is a bit brittle.
For the side parts <20% is sufficient (i used 15%) unless you want to give them to your dog as a chew toy.
You might glue the parts together with some super glue.

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Variable

Notes:

Support is not necessary.
Brim can be used for the base plate when there is the chance of warping, but cleaning the holes from the brim remainings afterwards is a bit fiddly.
If you print the side parts standing, i'd recommend a brim for some stability.

description.text: This project is for the KamerMaker, a mobile full scale 3d printing machine, that we are currently building in Amsterdam, Netherlands (http://www.kamermaker.com). The facade of the KamerMaker will be perforated and we will be insterting these wind turbines into the perforations. These designs are still preliminary so there are a few bugs we need to work out but we welcome your recommendations and tips.

There are 4 parts to the wind turbine design:
  • Wind mill holder with screw connection - part 1
  • Wind mill holder with screw connection - part 2
  • Mini motor with led - part 3 (http://www.dealextreme.com/p/wind-powered-led-light-for-vehicles-2-pack-5172)
  • Wind mill blades
    You can see some images of the design on our blog: http://www.dusarchitects.dds.nl/kamermaker/wordpress/?p=410

description.text:
This is a case for the TL Smoother diode board typically used to get smoother movement especially on a delta-style 3Dprinter using DVR8825 stepper drivers or A4988/2 drivers. It reduces the "salmon" effect where a pattern appears across the surface.

I used thermal paste to mount the heat-sink horizontally since the diodes can get hot.
This case is designed to use 2mm by 5mm long screws, however only one screw is needed since its such a tight fit when printed in ABS plastic.

The TL Smoother board I ordered was from Amazon, however the same model is available on ebay and other locations. The bottom of the board says: BIGTREETECH v1.0, it's dimensions are: 30mm by 40mm.

The search string to use on Amazon is: ARQQ TL Smoother Addon Module for Pattern Elimination Motor Clipping Filter 3D Printer Stepper Motor Drivers (Pack of 3pcs)

Update: I added a before and after TL-Smoother photo. See if you can guess which is which.

Printer:

Tevo Little Monster

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

20% or default

Notes:

When printing ABS I use a heated bed with Wolf Bite ABS formula so I do not need rafts. If you are printing without this formula you will probably need rafts.

comments.text: How did you mount these on your machine?
comments.author: casedog21

comments.text: I uploaded a picture showing how I mount them.  Basically double-sided sticky tape on the bottom of the 3D printed case.   Some in the facebook support group have mounted theirs above the control board case so air will flow over them from the control board cooling fan.   I have big heat-sinks so didn't worry about that.
comments.author: casedog21

comments.text: I didn't see anything about the heatsink you used... Just generic or something on amazon for the smoothers?
comments.author: brightlights

comments.text: Originally I planned to use 25x25mm and 10mm tall (minimum to cover diodes),  you could also get by with 28x28 20mm tall.  However after I noticed how hot they got I went with:  50x25mm and 10mm tall  (I would go with even taller ones if you have them).  The cutout in the sides of the case should accommodate both taller than 10mm and wider than 50mm.
comments.author: brightlights

title: Modified Mendel90 Y Bar Clamp with Optical Endstop Mount

description.text:
This is a modified version of the Dibond Mendel90 Y Bar Clamp by nophead which allows you to mount an optical endstop to your Y axis.

You will find the original Mendel90 Y bar clamps and instructions on how to install them inside nophead's GitHub repository: https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90/tree/master/dibond

Materials:

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

20 %

Assembly

You will need to cut two M3 threads into the 2.5 mm holes and after that you can install the endstop with the two M3 bolts.

title: Orvillian blaster Remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix /mod of the fantastic Orville blaster made by BiancaW
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2623867

First off, Thank you for Bianca for the wonderful sculpting...working off of screen caps is difficult.

As further episodes gave us more detail, I modified the blaster to fit the changes. The overall size is a little bigger/thicker and the grip has been extended to accommodate a larger hand. The front shroud angle was made more acute. I added three breakaway supports to the nose for ease of printing. A hollow was created on top for a lighted display using a T-1 LED, and channels for a AAA battery pack and wire runs put into each half. The trigger mechanism is a plunger designed to work with mini pushbuttons, and three T-5 LED sockets are hollowed in the nose emitter. The trigger well has a breakaway support, as well as the trigger plunger shaft. On the right half there are four small holes for thin case screws (pilot holes will need to be drilled.) I included a channel in the grip to add an optional master power micro switch, but a fresh set of batteries will run the top display for an entire weekend of cosplay without needing to be changed.

comments.text: Bianca's file has a no-derivative license on it though. So I don't think you're supposed to make derivatives.
comments.author: authormoreau

comments.text: Hi-- talked to Bianca---the derivative is significantly changed to the point where she is OK with having it on thingiverse for personal , but not commercial use.  Thanks.
comments.author: authormoreau

comments.text: Hi-- a while back when Bianca's first design was first put up, it had no restrictions (that's why I did the remix).  She did a follow on design available in Pinterest.  It looks like her original now has restrictions since she has the 2nd generation.  I'll contact her and see if she is OK with the rework I did (which is a significant changeup).  If she has any concerns I can remove the remix file.  Otherwise, I'll start from scratch and work up a design.
comments.author: authormoreau

comments.text: Cleaned up the wire channel runs a bit and added the fourth case screw at the top to keep it from opening slightly.  I would recommend using PLA to avoid warping, since the halves must be flat to join without a seam.

description.text: I created this myself using TinkerCAD to fit a lithophane I generated using the tool at 3dp.rocks/lithophane. I measured the lithophane I generated after printing it using some digital calipers and created a stand that can support the object. My lithophane was roughly 3mm thick and 100mm wide and fits snugly in this holder. This isn't perfectly symmetrical, but it's roughly there - I did it by eye, and didn't think it's worth the effort to get it perfect. It looks very nice when printed. The 'shorter' side of the middle piece should be for the front of the lithophane. I printed it using 'optimal' detail on an original Prusa i3 MK2s and sliced it using Slic3r Prusa edition.

title: 4th Axis Gimbal Stabilizer - Pro 2 Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm super happy with the new Pro 2 model. The footage is now 30% smoother than the original Pro 1 model!

I've made a number of videos on the stabilizer below;-

Features:- https://youtu.be/ydT-I7Mbt4o

Show-reel :- https://youtu.be/YFTraoByCp4

DIY video :- https://youtu.be/rivhUJsmm-I
Note: this is for the Compact Pro but for the most part it's identical.

DIY Spring changing video:- https://youtu.be/gBHZEe3udI8

Note: As with all of my designs that are also sold commercially, there's a small chance that it will only be available for a limited time so make sure you download while it's here :)

As I worked out from the popular Pro 1 model, many of you had difficulties tracking down all the parts needed... so now I'm selling a parts kit to make it super easy. This pack is designed for ‘Do it yourselfers’ who want to 3D print the bulk of the parts themselves. This parts kit includes all the fittings, springs, bearings, bolt runners, pre-filled fluid damping cartridges, speciality lubricants together with 3D printed parts that are a bit tricky to print yourself such as poly carbonate and bolt knobs. Full details in Post Printing section.

You can find the parts kit here:- https://scottymakesstuff.com/

The dreaded 'gimbal bob' will be a thing of the past with the silky smooth footage you'll get with the new full size Pro 2 Model 4th Axis Camera Stabilizer!

On the outside it’s got the same Pro 1 looks but that’s where the comparison ends. Every part has been tweaked and re-designed to squeeze every last bit of silky smooth goodness out of it.

The major changes in the new Pro 2 model are:-

  • It now floats effortlessly on 18 high quality bearings
  • The fluid damping has now gone crazy smooth with the addition of a new high tech synthetic damping gel
  • The geometry has been further tweaked for even softer load support

I think the biggest thing for me is that I can take everything I need for a shoot, lights, audio recorder and field monitor and it all fits in a backpack so there’s no need for an assistant and with my Zhiyun Remote mounted in the optional handle I can do away with a tripod and slider. But the real biggie is that you’ll be hard pressed to see the difference between footage shot on the new Pro 2 rig and the footage shot on a system totalling many thousands.

Some other important features;-

  • It’s built extra tough for the rigours of Pro use
  • It now includes a built in stand so you can rest your arms between takes
  • It’s adaptable with an ever growing eco-system of add ons for individualizing your rig
  • It’s been designed to be quiet so your audio won’t be ruined by the creaks and squeaks that those cheap Z stabilizers have.
  • And you don’t need a 10 pound padded shipping case to move it around. It all fits in a backpack!
  • You can leave the tools at home with tool-less adjustments in only seconds, not minutes
  • Pros can attach everything they need to your rig with 12 attachment points
  • And there’s 3 load springs to choose from for payloads from 2 to 10 pounds (0.9 to 4.5kg)
  • Dual independent adjustable fluid damping - from hard action to soft shots
  • Dual independent load adjusters to adapt to your rig
  • Adjust in seconds from high shot to upright to mid height to briefcase mode
  • Get buttery smooth footage with ease

Specifications

Weight 2.8 pounds (1.27kg)
Operating Temperatures -10C to 50C (14F-120F)
Payloads (Camera, gimbal and any extras)
945 Springs - light 2 to 5.5 pounds (0.9 to 2.5kg)
371 Springs - medium 2.9 to 6.6 pounds (1.3 to 3kg)
218 Springs - heavy 5 to 10 pounds (2.3 to 4.5kg)

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

You can see all my videos on my YouTube Channel, ScottyMakesStuff here:-
https://www.youtube.com/c/ScottyMakesStuff
https://twitter.com/ScottyMakesStuf
https://www.instagram.com/scottymakesstuff/

Notes:

To start, there are a lot of parts and each has specific instruction listed below. I suggest printing models in the orientation supplied. As this is a model that uses close tolerances (less than 0.2mm) your printer will have to be calibrated correctly or you'll have problems.

I use the triangular infill as it's good and strong. With my printers running at normal speeds and Simplify3D slicing I find all parts need little to no post printing work and fit perfectly... don't rush it! I print mine in an improved PLA. This is good to 55C (130F) degrees so don't leave it in a car on a very hot day... but the same should be said of any camera equipment so I think improved PLA will be best for 95% of you. You can try other filaments such as PETG, ABS or PC but you'd want to have a special set up and be a pro at getting those to work flawlessly.

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly.

GimbalSupport

Settings: 0.20mm layers, 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports,

SpringAdjust

Settings: 0.08mm - 0.20mm layers (see below), 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

It's important to print the rosettes at a fine layer height as these will mesh together and as such needs to be as accurate as possible. I printed mine at 0.10mm. Better still, if your slicer can print variable layer heights then you can print fine layers where it's needed and then speed up your prints significantly. In that case I'd suggest printing all but the rosette at 0.20mm to 0.30mm and printing just the rosette at 0.08mm.

Handles

Settings: 0.10 - 0.3mm layers (see below), 4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports, has a captured nut in each handle base

I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to the rosette I change the layer height to 0.10mm and then back to 0.3mm after 2mm of printing the rosette

The handles have captured bolts that will need to be inserted during the print. You can make sure you're there to pause the print and drop the nuts in or you could get a little funky with some gcode to stop the print for you. I typically use the free notepad++ to add some simple code to the gcode file just right before the covering layer is printed. Your printer will wait at this point until you hit resume. This is some example code (Note: please add X & Y coordinates to suit your print so that the print head gets out of the way for you) ;
; layer (whatever layer your print comes to), Z = 9.6 (depending on your print layer height the handle will need to be about this height when it stops)
; Add Nuts
M117 Add the nuts Scotty ; displays the message on your printer
G1 X(add your X coord here) Y(add your Y coord here) F8000 ; move out of way - you will need to work yours out relative to your print
M72 @pause ; pauses and plays the pause tune
M0
; inner perimeter

Alternatively the 'M600' change filament command works on many Marlin run printers. It's simple as all you need to add is a line with 'M600' in it and will often move the print head out of the way (depending on your printer). The only downside is that you will need to load the filament again.

I print mine at 0.30mm and when I get to the rosette I change the layer height to 0.10mm and then back to 0.3mm after 2mm of printing the rosette

SpringKnob & DampeningKnob

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3-4 perimeters, 25% fill

These two need to be printed in two parts. You need to print the top of the knob down to the start of the hole for the bolt head. Then you need print the other half with supports. Each slicer does this differently but there's plenty of online info about '3D printing in two halves'. Then I insert the bolt and use a 3D printing pen to fill the void making sure I go a little over the top. I then squeeze the lid down and hold it until it solidifies. You could use you printer to just extrude if you don't have a 3D pen. The other option is epoxy.

Note: These comes in the DIY pack already attached to bolts and nuts

GimbalScrewKnob & HandleKnob

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, No Supports

Note: These comes in the DIY pack already attached to bolts and nuts

TopArm and BottomArm

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3-4 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

DamperDynamicSide & DamperStaticSide

Settings: 0.15 to 0.20 mm layers , 3 perimeters, 25% fill, Supports

The dynamic side will also need to be thread tapped with a 6mm tap. You cam use a 6mm bolt but the end result isn't as easy to turn.
Note: This comes in the DIY pack already tapped and pre filled with high tech damping gel

The DIY Parts for the Pro 2 Kit has all the following parts:-

Note: You'll need to be a confident 3D printer with a accurately calibrated printer to print the main parts successfully.

16 x 6x13x5mm Steel bearings
2 x 6x10x3mm flanged steel bearing
2 x Poly Carbonate bolt runner with inserted brass nut
2 x Fluid damping cartridge - tapped and already filled with damping fluid
2 x springs (see description for details about the 3 available springs to choose from)
2 x M6 x 75mm SS Spring tension bolt mounted in knob
2 x M6 x 75mm SS Damping Adjustment bolt mounted in knob
2 x Rosette knobs with inserted M6 nut
1 x 1/4-20 x 3/4 in bolt mounted in gimbal attachment wheel
6 x 1/4 - 20 nuts for gimbal support and handle ends
1 x M6 x 35mm bolt mounted in Quad Pod knob
1 x M6 Socket
1 x 5mm allen key
6 x M6 Nylock nuts
2 x M6 x 35mm Stainless Steel bolts for rosettes
8 x M6 x 25mm socket head bolts
2 x M6 x 60mm socket head bolt
1 x sachet of bolt runner lubricant
1 x sachet of slide-way lubricant

comments.author: Outlawfab

comments.text: Thanks Outlawfab, the damping capsules need to be firstly threaded M6. I use a M6 thread tap but an M6 bolt will work ok. I use a modified plastic medical syringe to place the damping gel inside the capsules. I roughly fill them and then bring the two capsules together to distribute the gel. Then I do it again until the gel overflows out the centre indicating they're full. This takes approximately 3mls in each capsule.
comments.author: Outlawfab

comments.text: Hey Scotty.
comments.author: rene_onlineat

comments.text:
Thanks for the advice Rene :)
In the early development I trialled a system like you're suggesting. The off centre balance adds lever forces that apply additional strain to the wrist of the person holding it and it's harder to maintain a smooth image like that. I've never had any problem holding the handles, they're actually far more comfortable to hold and maneuver because of the inline loading. The Beholder is squeaky and the rated specs are just plain wrong... not to mention the price! My stabilizer has damping which allows it to produce far better stabilization in many more shooting situations. Probably the 4th axis stabilizer that's a better comparison is the Jockey... it has damping and payload support like mine... but I still think my stabilizer does a better job... Ok, I know I sound like a proud Dad but I'm proud for a very good reason! ;-)
comments.author: rene_onlineat

comments.text: Good day.  Would you (or someone) be so kind as to clarify the naming system employed for the springs utilized in this build.
comments.author: AbeScesse

comments.text:
Hi Abe, the spring names are just what I use to identify the 3 springs sold in the different parts kits and fully built stabilizers found at https://scottymakesstuff.com/
I made the parts kits because it was the biggest thing stopping people from making this design. People in the past had trouble ordering the correct springs as they had a minimum order amount of $50 at Century Springs. Also the damping gel has a minimum order of $70 and the bearings and some other parts weren't so easy to find. If you'd like to get the springs yourself from Century Springs then the full part names are 5945, 12371 and 218.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cy2SyPMwNWl

Hey guys.

As my first creation, I designed this phone stand as I find it a mix between guided design (I must respect the phone dimensions) and freedom of design.
The one in the photos is the first version. Since then I made a revision on the design to be more stable and to allow bigger clearance for the charging cable in the bottom.

The first model is suitable for phones up to 5.5" screen (maybe bigger if it has thin bezels like S8 and S8+). I believe the v2 will be able to handle slightly bigger phones, but not that bigger.

Print took about 3h in the first version, but I couldn't get proper bed adhesion so it has warped a bit reducing stability.

Looking forward to reading your feedback.

took inspiration from MakerBot's Headphone Stand
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050885
and

description.text:
This is a spool holder that I designed after trying to print TUSH https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047554
The bearings were to hard to fit so I tried to design something that you could print in small pieces and check if they fit and if not make adjustments and reprint without lots of material loss.

Also the holder is supposed to be printed on its side so you coud make it as wide as you want for extra stability.

For the whole thing you will need:
4 x 608 bearings
8 x Stand
2 x Holder

I printed the Holders in vase mode with 0.8mm wide perimeter, 0 bottom layers, 2mm brim and they turned ok.

The supplied Stand stl is with 7.7mm pins which fit fine with the bearings. The FreeCAD file is also there if you need to make any adjustments.

comments.text: I a fairly simple suggestion to your glider. when creating the wing, if any airfoil will be applied, do not choose an airfoil that provides lift, choose a symmetric airfoil shape. these are used on aerobatic planes, such as the red bull racing plane. if you do this, and keep it fairly thin, it wont flip around, but care must be taken into increasing the surface area of the elevators as well.

title: Micro 2.3" quad frame for Emax babyhawk power pack

description.text:
I wanted to try a 3D printed frame after smashing up the original Babyhawk frame and various small, cheap carbon frames. I was after a unique frame design that would resemble some larger freestyle quad designs using a lower set top plate to bring the centre of gravity down.

This design worked well especially for the Emax power pack components with an upgraded Micro camera and VTX.

I'll also attach another frame design with a higher top plate to suit a 20x20x23mm stack if you would like a higher performing micro quad.

The TPU camera mount was designed by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2470419

The Emax Femto F3 flight controller holder was remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2041827

The board holder was remixed to remove the 20x20 mounting holes and to add a gap to run beeper wires out from under the board.

Printer:

Custom HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used a triangle infill in S3D which seems to be working really well.

Use a higher grade Pro PLA for stronger results and run a slightly higher temp if you can to really fuse the layers together.

Motor screw hole sizes

The screw holes are designed to be slightly smaller for the motors. You will need to use a drill bit to ream out the holes to suit the size of your motor screws.

I mainly used M2 screws through the build but you can use M2.5 or even M3 if you wish just by drilling the holes out. Choose a screw length to suit. Self tapping crews in the TPU camera holder will make it stronger.

15mm stand offs used on the Emax Power Pack version.

20mm stand offs on the 20x20mm stack version.

description.text:
Having tried the Active Cooling Duct for the CTC Dual printer, and failing to get the bridging results I was after, I decided to make my own design. The ducts I have tried using have a single fan to cool 2 nozzles, so I decided to have a 2 fan duct. One for each nozzle.

I also wanted to make fitting easier. Many of the ducts I looked at required really long screws, and the active duct uses clips but they are screwed down. I wanted to just use sprung snap on fixings. They worked a treat for me.

title: Wall Mounted Filament Rack and Dispenser

description.text:
A remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1047639

Changes and improvements

  1. Shortened up the wall brackets and carriages. My spools would not fit in the original without rubbing. Also, my ANET A8 print bed is not large enough to print the original wall brackets.
  2. Added a center bracket as I noticed some sagging when fully loaded.
  3. Added bottom guides in the bearing slots to keep them from falling through when trying to install the carriages.
  4. Created a filament guide as I wanted to be able to feed from all spools without moving them to a single carriage. (Note: this filament guide will work with the original design)
  5. Created clip on name tags to label the type of filament. (Remixed this clip to make the tags: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30738)

What you will need:
Qty 2: 5/16" Steel Rod (I used 3ft lengths)
Qty 4: 608ZZ bearings (Per Carriage) - 32 for 8 carriages.
Qty 4: M3 Nuts (Per Carriage) - 32 for 8 carriages
Qty 3: M3x16 Bolts (Per Carriage) - 24 for 8 carriages
Qty 1: M3x20 Bolts (Per Carriage) - 8 for 8 carriages
The longer bolt is for the spot where the filament guide is mounted. You could use longer bolts for any of these as they will not interfere with anything.

I also added 4 of these handy rod end clamps as the caps that came with the original did nothing to prevent the rods from sliding around. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1243969
You will need an additional 4 M3 nuts and 4 M3x8 bolts for these.

P.S. If you are looking for a similar design with much less printing time involved, be sure to check out https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:557090 I was too far into this build when I found that one, but it would also not allow me to have my filament guides installed the way I or be mounted directly to the wall.

Printer:

ANET A8

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the name tags face down on glass so I could paint the lettering and wipe away excess from the surface easily.

I also have just slowly printed carriages since this entire build is quite a lot of printing time. I created a GCode file with a complete carriage set and fire it off when I am not printing something else, such as before bed. Still printing the last two as you will see from the pictures.

The main problem was that the code I based it on made use of Timer0 and this timer is used by the Arduino millis() function which many Arduino libraries make use of. author: Seafax

description.text:
Quickest Mod I’ve Done,,, this Removes the Ball Ends so they can be Printed Separately or if you have Broking your Ballends you can Print Replacement Ones,,,

Ohh Yeah,,, don’t forget to “Hot Tap” the Screws in or you will properly split them again,, just use a Candle or a Tea light – heat the tip of the screw until you just feel the head staring to burn your finger tip- (See Pic )

The Screw Hole is 2.5mm and the Ball is 12mm Dia -

The Main Plate was a bit Butchers during the Conversion from STL cos of the Hi-Res of the Object but luckily it was only on non- critical areas (rounded edges,),, the good thing is that the errors all match so you wouldn’t no the difference if you didn’t know what you where looking for ––,, I wasn’t going to upload the main plate since Broken Ballends seamed to be problem but what the hell,,, its there if ya need it-

I'm using Alans STL files at the moment (I think) - So if he has the time to do the same mod with the Original file I’ll take this one Down—

Many Thanks to Bob&Alan for uploading there work,,,,

-=Mindless=-

P.S-- Didn't put it as a Re-mix because i'm not sure who work i'm actually remixing,,,

author: zephur

description.text:
My wife has a tough time seeing. When we are out walking you have to tell her when there are steps so that she does not trip or fall down. Because of this I decided to design a handheld device that could tell her when the ground changes either up or down using a ultra sonic sensor and two LED lights. Red for step up, yellow for step down.

The program captures the distance and compares the next captured value and flashes the appropriate lights or none at all.

I designed the handle to include the battery, found a movable sensor holder that I modified some so that the tool could have other functions if wanted (distance from an object id the first thing that comes to mind.

This is still a prototype and I will be working on a better version that will run on a feather, greatly reducing the size of the tool. Also want to modify the code so that the lights only flash when there is a specific change in the height (like 1 inch).

You will need support material for the front and back. You will also need to print 2 of the rings.
Christmas tree earrings I made for my flatmates

description.text: I did not want to spend money on the official Baratza portaholder so I made my own. If you want to print it, be careful: it probably only fits with the Saeco Aroma. I recommend you design your own version... I just wanted to share the idea.

comments.text: Thank you so much for making this and sharing! I thought it was a really good idea but it didn't quite solve my problem. I printed this in an effort to reduce the mess the grinder makes when I grind directly into my portafilter or at least catch grinds that miss the portafilter. When I tried using this stand, a lot of grinds ended up in front of the grinder. I think I'm going to continue holding the portafilter against the top of the opening to avoid making a mess and come up with another solution for catching grinds underneath. Since this device fits nice and snug, I might try to modify it to use the base to make a container. I'm also thinking of trying to find something like this for the Saeco Aroma's porta filter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:716098
comments.author: Mustack
